title: A beginners experience in League of Legends
body:
Hi Riot, 

**1. New players wont have access to all summoner spells and masteries**
This is like people trying football for the first time but since they are new, they are not allowed to have a keeper and they have to wear flip flops, while their experienced opponents fucking demolish their team. But hey, at least you can ghost and heal to safety.  

**2. New players have to be level 10 to use the practice tool**
Cause God forbit them getting better at the game before entering competitive gameplay

**3. Players that aren't new but creates a new account can click a field stating that they are experienced players**
That does not keep Riot from forcing you to play vs bots for 5 hours - not learning anything a damn thing. 

I hope you will look into this someday cause this might be why your dropout rate has increased significantly for that past 8 months. 

Ok, bye

Honestly, they should just ask at the very beginning when someone signs up "Would you like a learning account?"

Then, if the player answers "yes," they can go through the leveling process, most likely with other new players.  "No" responses could just start at level 30 with runes unlocked.

This would reduce about 90% of raging smurfs in the newbie games.  *Most* of these individuals aren't the "special" kind that rerolls for the explicit purpose of trashing nubs.  The vast majority of them are just rerolling their account because their main was banned (probably for toxicity), and they just want to get to 30 ASAP.  Give them a one-click button to get them out of the newbie area.

I think the core takeaway here is that, while it is indeed important to properly guide new players, especially in a complicated game like League, doing so via hard restrictions and railroading is just about the worst way of going about things. The limits imposed on summoner spells and masteries are completely arbitrary, and serve only to force newer players into weaker builds so that they get bodied even harder at the start. Worse still, it often teaches the wrong things to players, as it pushes them to play in a manner that is completely different from the way League actually gets played. This itself is compounded by the bot games players are pushed into, because bots don't jungle. It may not be quite as bad as Thornmail on Ashe, but it's the same kind of terrible tutorial design that forces even _more_ of a learning barrier onto new players, because they have to unlearn a ton of bad habits in addition to re-learning the whole game in order to play properly. Moreover, the restrictions themselves feel terrible, so the system altogether feels like it's more likely to push players _away_ from League, instead of facilitating onboarding. I'm looking forward to the revamped new player experience Riot is proposing, but if it's going to continue imposing arbitrary restrictions upon newer players, it's going to fall flat on its face.
